nvironmental consequences. Looking ahead, a development pathway that

on the role of poverty and inequality as drivers of GHG emissions

environmental quality and may be associated with higher GHG

employment status, urban vs rural location and housing stock
evidence to indicate that at the household level, the increase in emissions from additional consumption
of the lower income households could be larger than the reduction in emissions from the drop in
consumption from the high income households
. Accordingly, as countries seek to fulfil

ng the relationships of income inequality and emissions by looking at

Concerns about mitigation are already being introduced in national development plans, as there is
evidence that development strategies and pathways can be carefully designed so as to align towards
multiple priorities and achieve greater synergistic benefit
s. For example, Indias solar programme is a
